bibl.title: Report: Microscopic examination of Dr. Muller's slides, by Samuel Taylor Darling, [January 1924]

div1.p: An examination of the tissue slides indicates no evidence of yellow fever.

div1.head: Report: Microscopic examination of Dr. Muller's slides, by Samuel Taylor Darling, [January 1924]
div1.p:
Microscopic examination of Dr. Muller's
slides of tissue marked, “Tissues of woman patient
referred to in Dr. Hanson's letter of
November sixth.”

Liver. This is a very fatty liver. The fat droplets being usu-
ally of large size and contained in cells the nucleus of which is frequently
pushed to one side but stains in normal manner. The cytoplasm of the cell
stains normally and shows no hyaline necrosis as in yellow fever. A number of
the portal spaces show round cell proliferation. The sections stained for fat
show many large fat droplets and some of smaller size, but the cell nucleus is
always well defined.

Kidney. Post-mortem changes obscure the picture. There is an
increase in the intertubular connection tissue. This is usually fibrous in
character and is well marked beneath the capsule. The glomeruli are fibrous.
Bowman's Capsule is markedly thickened. Some of the blood vessels show well
marked thickening of the intima and there is a small hypernephroma or adenoma
in the cortex.

list.head: Diagnosis:
list.item: 2. Round cell proliferation of portal spaces.

div1.p: There are no evidences of yellow fever.

closer.signed:
Signed, Samuel T. Darling
S. T. Darling, M. D.
